oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Board of Trade affidavit and invoice for Joseph Ambrose
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Tennessee -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865; United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865 -- Economic aspects; United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865 -- Transportation; Affidavits; Permits; Oaths; Nashville (Tenn.); East, Edward H., 1830-1904
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: One-page printed and handwritten Board of Trade affidavit represents the oath of Joseph Ambrose that the supplies for which he requests transportation are a requirement for his family in Nashville and will be used solely for that purpose. Surveyor of Customs Edward H. East signed the affidavit. The attached invoice lists the family goods. All of this documentation had to be in place to receive a permit or a recommendation of the Board of Trade.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Board of Trade (Nashvile, Tenn.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Record Group 21, Adjutant General's Office Records, 1796-1900
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: When trade privileges were restored to Tennessee on March 5, 1863, trade permits were at first issued by special U. S. Treasury agent Allen A. Hall, but a month later Military Governor Andrew Johnson directed applications to be sent to Tennessee Secretary of State Edward H. East or A. V. S. Lindsley. East would be appointed president of the Nashville Board of Trade when Treasury agent W. P. Mellen arrived in Nashville on May 15, 1863, to officially organize a board of trade.
